metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: Git Rebase
What is Git Rebase?
Rebasing moves or combines a sequence of commits to a new base commit.
content.html: Rebasing moves or combines a sequence of commits to a new base commit.

content.text: It is often used to keep a clean, linear project history.
content.html: It is often used to keep a clean, linear project history.

content.text: Rebasing can make your commit history easier to read by avoiding unnecessary merge commits.
content.html: Rebasing can make your commit history easier to read by avoiding unnecessary merge commits.

content.text: When to Use Git Rebase
Use Git Rebase to:
content.html: Use Git Rebase to:

content.text: Basic Rebase
To move your current branch on top of another branch (e.g., update your feature branch with latest main):
content.html: To move your current branch on top of another branch (e.g., update your feature branch with latest main):

content.code:
git
checkout feature-branch

git
rebase main
content.code_html:
git checkout feature-branch
git rebase main

content.text: This reapplies your feature branch changes on top of the latest main branch.
content.html: This reapplies your feature branch changes on top of the latest main branch.

content.text: Interactive Rebase
git rebase -i < base > lets you edit, reorder, squash, or fix up commits before a certain point.
content.html: git rebase -i <base> lets you edit, reorder, squash, or fix up commits before a certain point.

content.text: This is useful for cleaning up your commit history before sharing it with others.
content.html: This is useful for cleaning up your commit history before sharing it with others.

content.code_html: git rebase -i HEAD~3

content.text: This opens an editor where you can:
content.html: This opens an editor where you can:

content.text: Follow these steps:
content.html: Follow these steps:

content.text: Continue, Abort, or Skip
If you hit a conflict or need to finish editing a commit, use git rebase --continue after resolving the issue.
content.html: If you hit a conflict or need to finish editing a commit, use git rebase --continue after resolving the issue.

content.text: This tells Git to keep going with the rebase process.
content.html: This tells Git to keep going with the rebase process.

content.code_html:
git add fixed_file.txt
git rebase --continue

content.text: If something goes wrong or you want to stop the rebase, use git rebase --abort .
content.html: If something goes wrong or you want to stop the rebase, use git rebase --abort.

content.text: This will put your branch back to how it was before you started rebasing.
content.html: This will put your branch back to how it was before you started rebasing.

content.code_html: git rebase --abort

content.text: If you can't fix a commit during a rebase (for example, if a conflict can't be resolved), you can skip it with git rebase --skip .
content.html: If you can't fix a commit during a rebase (for example, if a conflict can't be resolved), you can skip it with git rebase --skip.

content.text: Git will leave out that commit and move on to the next one.
content.html: Git will leave out that commit and move on to the next one.

content.code_html: git rebase --skip

content.text: Review Changes
After completing the rebase, review your changes to ensure everything is correct.
content.html: After completing the rebase, review your changes to ensure everything is correct.

content.text: Tips & Best Practices
Rebasing rewrites commit history.
content.html: Rebasing rewrites commit history.

content.text: Avoid rebasing commits that you have already pushed to a shared repository.
content.html: Avoid rebasing commits that you have already pushed to a shared repository.

content.text: Use git rebase -i to edit, reorder, squash, or fix up commits before a certain point.
content.html: Use git rebase -i to edit, reorder, squash, or fix up commits before a certain point.

content.text: Use git rebase --continue to continue a rebase after resolving conflicts.
content.html: Use git rebase --continue to continue a rebase after resolving conflicts.

content.text: Use git rebase --abort to cancel a rebase in progress.
content.html: Use git rebase --abort to cancel a rebase in progress.

content.text: Troubleshooting
If you encounter conflicts during a rebase, resolve them and then use git rebase --continue to continue the rebase process.
content.html: If you encounter conflicts during a rebase, resolve them and then use git rebase --continue to continue the rebase process.

content.text: If you can't fix a commit during a rebase, use git rebase --skip to skip it.
content.html: If you can't fix a commit during a rebase, use git rebase --skip to skip it.

content.text: Note: Rebasing rewrites commit history.
content.html: Note: Rebasing rewrites commit history.

content.text: Avoid rebasing commits that you have already pushed to a shared repository.
content.html: Avoid rebasing commits that you have already pushed to a shared repository.
